text: this is quite unusual behaviour for
polar bears it has happened in the past
where polar bears essentially go to
villages to search out food they look
for bins and they scavenge and obviously
there's livestock and pets as well the
sea ice is melting earlier in the year
and refreezing later they can't get out
onto the sea ice to hunt the seals so
they're attracted into the communities
by the smell of food and also by the
smell of rubbish of waste dumps it's
becoming increasingly common right
across the Arctic incidences of human
polar bear conflict polar bears tend to
live quite solitary lives so to find
them in big congregations is really
unusual bears don't tend to hunt humans
we're not their natural source of prey
livestock maybe the thing is is once
Bears get really really hungry they'll
eventually start picking off people for
people who live in the Arctic
communities if their family or their
property is at risk the most likely
thing they will do would be to shoot
those polar bears we want to ensure that
it's not going to happen we're equipping
local people and local communities with
the tools that they need to try and
drive these polar bears out of their
communities using non-lethal techniques
crackers sirens and alarms anything that
will drive the polar bears away from the
communities the errant polar bears
coming into communities are trapped
they're locked away in the jail and that
helps them to associate coming into
contact with human beings as a bad
experience and they're relocated
hundreds of kilometres away by
helicopter
this involves infrared sensors so they
can identify an animal at a species
level and purely by its shape and they
can also tell you about the direction of
travel of that particular animal polar
bear controls can then go out and chase
that bear away before it puts children
and other villages at risk
[Music]
